Question: How is my blood sugar controlled? Should I do anything else?
A: I can control my blood sugar by drinking a lot of water; it dilutes the sugar in my blood.
B: Control your blood sugar with regular monitoring. Follow your diet, treatment, and physical activity to avoid high blood sugar. Consult a doctor if you have symptoms.
C: My blood sugar is controlled solely by my diet; as long as I eat balanced meals, I don't have to worry.
D: My blood sugar is controlled by my stress level; if I'm relaxed, my sugar level is good.

Question: My control has been good so far, but is it likely to deteriorate with age as my metabolism changes?
A: Yes, diabetes control can deteriorate with age due to metabolic changes. Regular monitoring and treatment adjustment are essential.
B: Yes, diabetes always worsens with age; there's nothing you can do about it.
C: No, your diabetes is stable once you have achieved good control; aging has no impact.
D: Your diabetes will only worsen if you gain weight as you get older.

Question: How can I better control my blood sugar?
A: Drinking sugary fruit juices is a good way to manage blood sugar because they contain natural sugars.
B: Eating a lot of sugar before sleeping helps stabilize blood sugar during the night.
C: Ignoring mild symptoms is acceptable because diabetes only becomes dangerous at an advanced stage.
D: Control your blood sugar through a balanced diet, exercise, regular monitoring, and medical follow-up.

Question: If I don't take medication, can I keep the disease under control by losing weight?
A: Losing weight helps control diabetes, but a healthy diet and exercise are also essential.
B: Losing weight is enough; you don't need to watch what you eat or exercise.
C: No, weight loss has no impact on diabetes; only medication can control it.
D: Yes, losing weight completely cures diabetes, so you won't need medication anymore.

Question: Why do I have to take insulin?
A: Insulin strengthens your heart and blood vessels.
B: Insulin is a medication that replaces a poor diet.
C: Insulin helps you lose weight and get in better shape.
D: You take insulin because your body doesn't produce enough or is resistant to it, which helps regulate your blood sugar and prevent complications.

Question: Would a better diet help to manage without insulin?
A: Yes, a special plant-based diet can cure diabetes and eliminate the need for insulin.
B: Yes, if you eat a lot of vegetables, your body will produce enough insulin so you won't need injections anymore.
C: No, a better diet doesn't eliminate the need for insulin for type 1 diabetes, but it helps control blood sugar and improve health.
D: Yes, a very strict diet with no sugar can replace insulin for all types of diabetes.

Question: Why is my blood sugar fluctuating? And why can't I control it?
A: Your blood contains too much sugar and your body is trying to get rid of it by making it fluctuate.
B: It's because of what you ate last week; sugar takes a long time to leave your body.
C: Blood sugar fluctuates due to diet, activity, stress, illness, or inadequate treatment. Sleep also impacts it. Regular monitoring is essential.
D: Your body is simply confused and doesn't know how to manage sugar correctly.

Question: Is there a definitive CURE for diabetes?
A: There are new surgeries that can remove the part of the body that causes diabetes, thus permanently curing it.
B: There is no definitive cure for diabetes, but treatment combining medication and non-medicinal measures is essential for effectively managing it.
C: You can get rid of diabetes by following a very strict diet and exercising a lot.
D: Yes, you can be completely cured of diabetes by taking specific pills to lower sugar.

Question: HOW TO STAY MORE POSITIVE ABOUT MY CONDITION?
A: Focus only on your blood sugar numbers to motivate yourself.
B: Compare yourself to other people with diabetes to see that you are less affected.
C: Avoid talking about your diabetes so you don't think about it.
D: To stay positive, focus on positive aspects, surround yourself with support, practice gratitude, take physical care of yourself, and start your days positively.

Question: I WOULD LIKE MORE INFORMATION ABOUT DIABETIC NEUROPATHY.
A: Diabetic neuropathy is a foot infection that often occurs in diabetics.
B: Diabetic neuropathy is a mental illness caused by stress related to diabetes.
C: Diabetic neuropathy: nerve damage caused by hyperglycemia, resulting in pain, numbness, digestive/urinary issues. Good blood sugar control slows its progression.
D: Diabetic neuropathy is an allergic reaction to diabetes medication.

Question: OVER THE LAST SIX MONTHS, I'VE NOTICED I'M FORGETTING MORE AND MORE THINGS. COULD THIS BE ATTRIBUTED TO MY DIABETES?
A: Forgetfulness is part of normal aging, not diabetes.
B: Your blood sugar is too low, which temporarily disrupts your brain.
C: Diabetes only affects your blood sugar level, not your memory.
D: Yes, diabetes, especially poorly controlled diabetes, can affect memory. Consult your doctor.

Question: I AM CURRENTLY BEING EXAMINED FOR POSSIBLE SLEEP APNEA. COULD THIS BE LINKED TO DIABETES?
A: Sleep apnea is caused by type 1 diabetes, as thin people with type 1 diabetes often have breathing problems.
B: Only gestational diabetes in pregnant women can be linked to sleep apnea due to hormonal changes.
C: Yes, sleep apnea is linked to type 2 diabetes, often due to overweight. It can also complicate the management of your diabetes.
D: No, sleep apnea is a lung problem and diabetes is a blood sugar problem; they have no link.

Question: My blood sugar has been HIGH for a long time. Can the side effects be improved again?
A: Side effects disappear on their own over time.
B: Yes, controlling your blood sugar through diet, exercise, and treatment can improve diabetes complications.
C: Diabetes complications only affect elderly people.
D: Just drinking a lot of water is enough to lower blood sugar.

Question: Will there be a CURE for diabetes?
A: Diabetes goes away on its own if you eat a lot of sugar to 'balance' the body.
B: Yes, a new magic pill has been discovered that cures diabetes overnight.
C: Diabetes is a chronic disease that is treated but not yet cured. Research for a cure is ongoing.
D: Only children develop diabetes, and it disappears as they get older.

Question: CAN I HAVE AN IMPLANT THAT MAKES INSULIN FOR ME?
A: No, the body cannot accept an organ replacement like the pancreas that produces insulin.
B: No, there is no implant to produce insulin; only an injection can do that.
C: Yes, experimental implants exist to automatically deliver insulin by detecting your blood sugar, but they are not yet available to the public.
D: Yes, but only if the diabetes is mild and the implant doesn't need to produce much insulin.

Question: CAN THE GLAND START WORKING AGAIN?
A: Yes, a gland can start working again if the cause of the dysfunction is treated, but not always.
B: Yes, you just need to massage the area where the gland is located or take vitamin supplements to help it restart.
C: Yes, if you eat certain foods like honey or turmeric, it can stimulate the gland and make it work again.
D: No, once a gland stops working, it is permanently damaged and can never recover.

Question: WHY DOES STRESS INCREASE MY BLOOD SUGAR?
A: Stress increases blood sugar because it slows down the digestion and absorption of sugars.
B: Stress increases blood sugar because it makes you want to eat sugary foods more.
C: Stress increases blood sugar by releasing hormones that stimulate glucose production and reduce insulin sensitivity.
D: Stress increases blood sugar because it exhausts the body, preventing it from using sugar correctly.

Question: CAN AN INSULIN PUMP HELP CONTROL BLOOD SUGAR BETTER THAN INSULIN PENS?
A: Insulin pumps are preferable because they completely eliminate the need to control blood sugar yourself.
B: Yes, an insulin pump can better control blood sugar by delivering insulin continuously and adapting to lifestyle, with fewer injections.
C: Insulin pumps are more expensive, so they must be more effective to justify their high cost.
D: An insulin pump is always more effective because it uses a different and more powerful type of insulin than pens.

Question: WHY ARE MY HANDS AND MY FEET SO AFFECTED by diabetes?
A: Diabetes medications have side effects that primarily affect the hands and feet.
B: Diabetes causes poor general blood circulation throughout the body, which affects the extremities the most.
C: Diabetes weakens the bones in the hands and feet, making them more fragile and sensitive.
D: High blood sugar damages nerves and vessels in hands/feet, causing numbness, poor healing, and infection risk.

Question: WILL I EVER STOP TAKING INSULIN AND TABLETS AT THE SAME TIME?
A: Yes, after a few years, diabetes disappears and you won't need treatment anymore.
B: Yes, if you exercise a lot, your body will produce enough insulin for you to stop.
C: Type 1 requires lifelong insulin. Type 2 may stop insulin if controlled, but may need it later. Always consult your doctor before changing treatment.
D: Yes, if you stop eating sugar, you won't need insulin or tablets anymore.

Question: WHAT ABOUT AN INSULIN PUMP?
A: An insulin pump is a device that helps digest sugar faster so it doesn't stay in the blood.
B: An insulin pump delivers insulin continuously or on demand to better control blood sugar, as an alternative to injections.
C: An insulin pump is a type of treatment that completely replaces oral medications for type 2 diabetes.
D: An insulin pump is a device that measures blood sugar level and automatically injects the necessary insulin.

Question: What are the INJECTION SITES?
A: Insulin is injected under the skin in 4 areas: abdomen, arms, buttocks, and thighs.
B: Insulin is injected directly into a vein for fast action.
C: Insulin is injected under the tongue to be absorbed.
D: Only the heart area is an insulin injection site.

Question: How can I avoid BRUISES?
A: Apply cold, avoid heat, elevate and rest the area. Arnica, vitamin K, or aloe vera can help.
B: Bruises are a sign that you are lacking calcium; you need to take more.
C: To avoid bruises, you need to massage very hard as soon as you bump yourself.
D: You must apply heat immediately to make the bruise disappear faster.

Question: ARE HIGH LFT RESULTS DUE TO DIABETES?
A: No, high liver tests are only linked to alcohol consumption, not diabetes.
B: Yes, diabetes always causes high liver function test results because sugar directly attacks the liver.
C: Diabetes can raise LFTs, but other causes exist. Consult a doctor for an accurate diagnosis.
D: No, diabetes only affects the kidneys and eyes, not the liver.

Question: WHAT ARE THE LONG-TERM IMPLICATIONS OF HIGH GLUCOSE LEVEL?
A: Having a high glucose level means you naturally have more energy.
B: A high glucose level can make you more susceptible to catching colds.
C: A high glucose level makes you gain weight quickly and effortlessly.
D: High glucose level can damage kidneys, eyes, nerves, heart, and cause fatigue, thirst, frequent urination, weight loss.

Question: HOW TO PREVENT DIABETES PROGRESSION?
A: Healthy lifestyle: balanced diet, physical activity, quitting smoking, weight/blood pressure/cholesterol/glucose control, stress/sleep management prevent diabetes progression.
B: Just taking diabetes medication is enough to prevent it from worsening, without changing habits.
C: Diabetes is genetic, so nothing can be done to prevent its progression.
D: Taking vitamins regularly can be enough to prevent diabetes from getting worse.

Question: IF BLOOD SUGAR IS HIGH, WHAT SHOULD I DO?
A: Just rest; the body will regulate the sugar level on its own.
B: Drinking a lot of sugary water helps dilute sugar in the blood.
C: Eating a candy to balance the sugar level will make it go down.
D: Monitor diet, exercise, control your blood sugar, and consult a doctor.

Question: Why is my blood sugar never CONSTANT, always RISING AND FALLING?
A: It's because your pancreas is tired and no longer produces insulin.
B: Your variations are normal as long as you don't feel bad.
C: Your blood sugar varies depending on diet, activity, stress, etc. Keep it within the normal range to avoid complications (hypo/hyperglycemia).
D: This means your body is fighting an infection.

Question: HOW TO BALANCE DIET, ACTIVITY, AND INSULIN, ESPECIALLY WHEN WORK ACTIVITY IS NOT CONSTANT?
A: You can eat whatever you want as long as you exercise more to burn extra calories.
B: Just eat less on days when you are less professionally active to compensate.
C: Balance a varied diet (slow carbohydrates), regular physical activity, and adjust insulin with a professional, especially if your work varies.
D: The important thing is to always take the same dose of insulin at the same time, regardless of activity.

Question: WHAT ARE THE MAIN ADVANCES IN CARE AND WHEN CAN PATIENTS BENEFIT FROM THEM?
A: There will be new sugary pills that will replace insulin.
B: Patients will soon be able to eat whatever they want thanks to new medications.
C: We can cure diabetes by drinking a new special drink.
D: New drug combinations for diabetes: basal insulin + GLP-1 and DPP-4i + SGLT2i (the latter not yet in France).

Question: WHAT ARE THE SERIOUS SIDE EFFECTS OF DIABETES MEDICATIONS?
A: Taking diabetes medications can damage the liver and kidneys over time.
B: Diabetes medications can cause widespread skin rashes and intense itching.
C: Rare serious side effects: diabetic ketoacidosis, Fournier's gangrene. Others: hypoglycemia, vomiting, pain, infections, diarrhea.
D: Diabetes medications can make bones fragile and cause fractures.

Question: WHAT IS MYOPATHY AND IS THERE ANYTHING I CAN DO ABOUT IT?
A: Myopathy is a fancy term for muscle soreness, and it gets better with rest and pain relievers.
B: Myopathy affects muscles, making daily activities difficult. Treatment varies depending on the type and severity.
C: Myopathy is a nerve problem that causes tingling in the hands and feet, and it goes away over time.
D: Myopathy is a fungal skin infection that can be treated with over-the-counter creams.

Question: IS THERE AN ALTERNATIVE TO INSULIN?
A: Yes, there are herbal remedies that completely cure diabetes without needing insulin.
B: Yes, alternatives to insulin exist, such as oral medications or leptin, but their effectiveness varies and they are not suitable for everyone. Consult your doctor.
C: Yes, you can replace insulin with a simple diet and exercise.
D: No, insulin is the only treatment for diabetes.

Question: CAN I TAKE MY "BASAL" AT A DIFFERENT TIME OF DAY FOR BETTER CONTROL?
A: Maybe, if you take your "basal" before a heavy meal, it can stabilize your blood sugar.
B: Yes, changing the time you take it can help your body absorb the medication better.
C: No, always take your basal insulin at the same time each day.
D: It depends; if you have high symptoms, you can take it earlier for quick relief.

Question: ARE THERE SIMPLER WAYS TO CONTROL BLOOD SUGAR?
A: Eating only fruits and vegetables will guarantee you normal blood sugar effortlessly.
B: Skipping meals is a good way to lower your blood sugar quickly.
C: Control your blood sugar simply: monitor it, eat balanced meals (fiber, low GI), exercise, and follow your treatment.
D: Drinking lots of water can alone replace the need for treatment or a specific diet.

Question: HOW TO ACTUALLY REDUCE MY BASAL INSULIN LEVEL - EXERCISE, DIET, WEIGHT LOSS?
A: Drink lots of lemon water to "cleanse" the system and reduce insulin needs.
B: Eat lots of sugary foods so the body produces less insulin.
C: Regular exercise and adapted diet reduce basal insulin.
D: Take regular cold showers to stimulate metabolism.

Question: How to manage INSULIN RESISTANCE?
A: Drink lots of fruit juice because it's sweet and gives cells energy.
B: Managing insulin resistance involves a healthy diet, regular exercise, good sleep, and sometimes medications like metformin.
C: Completely avoid all carbohydrates, as they are the sole cause of insulin resistance.
D: Eat lots of sugar so the body produces more insulin and fights resistance.

Question: What is the NEED FOR MORE FREQUENT SITE ROTATION?
A: It's to prevent insulin from becoming less effective over time.
B: Rotating injection sites prevents bruising, infection, inflammation, fat deposits, and absorption issues.
C: It's to give the muscles a rest after the injection.
D: It's so the body doesn't get used to insulin too quickly.

Question: IS THERE INFORMATION ON PROGRESS IN TERMS OF CURE, TRANSPLANTATION, ETC?
A: A cure for diabetes is imminent thanks to a new gene therapy.
B: You can cure diabetes by eating certain foods and exercising.
C: Yes, new pills can cure diabetes in a few weeks.
D: Pancreas transplantation is a life-saving treatment for diabetes.

Question: IS THERE A POSSIBILITY THAT CHILDREN WILL INHERIT DIABETES?
A: No, diabetes in children is always caused by a poor diet.
B: Yes, but only if both parents have diabetes.
C: Yes, type 1 diabetes is hereditary, but the risk of transmission to children is low.
D: No, diabetes is a disease that affects only adults.

Question: HOW COULD I HAVE CONTRACTED DIABETES WITHOUT EVER BEING OVERWEIGHT AND WITH GOOD BLOOD PRESSURE?
A: Diabetes can be a contagious disease that you caught from another person.
B: Type 2 diabetes can be caused by genetics, sedentary lifestyle, poor diet, or aging, even without being overweight or having high blood pressure.
C: You might have eaten too much sugar at once, which overloaded your pancreas and caused diabetes.
D: It's probably related to stress; chronic stress can mess with your blood sugar level.

Question: WHAT IS THE RISK OF ORGAN DAMAGE IN A DIABETIC PERSON?
A: It's mostly a blood sugar problem that makes people tired, but it doesn't really damage organs.
B: The risk is mostly related to being overweight; diabetes itself does not directly cause organ damage.
C: Diabetes damages organs mainly because the body can no longer produce enough insulin, leading to poor digestion.
D: Chronic high blood sugar damages blood vessels and affects kidneys, eyes, nerves, heart, and arteries.

Question: DOES VISION DETERIORATE FASTER WITH DIABETES?
A: Yes, diabetes can damage the eye (retina, lens, etc.), causing progressive vision loss. Good blood sugar control and regular eye exams are essential.
B: No, vision does not deteriorate faster with diabetes; it's a myth.
C: Yes, but only if you don't wear glasses suited to your vision.
D: No, vision deterioration is due to normal aging, not diabetes.

Question: WILL ALL TYPE 2 DIABETES PATIENTS EVENTUALLY NEED INSULIN?
A: Only if their diabetes is very severe and they don't follow their doctor's advice.
B: No, not all. Some control their type 2 diabetes with lifestyle and oral medications. Insulin may become necessary if control is insufficient.
C: Yes, it's a progressive disease and insulin is always the last step in treatment.
D: It depends on their age; older people will certainly need insulin.

Question: What to do about skin infections in diabetics?
A: Using special moisturizing creams for diabetics is enough to prevent and treat them.
B: You need to drain skin infections to remove the pus and speed up healing.
C: Control your blood sugar, maintain hygiene, and consult a doctor to treat skin infections.
D: Drinking lots of water and eating less sugar will solve the problem of skin infections.

Question: CAN TYPE II DIABETES BE "CURED" OR ONLY MANAGED?
A: It can be permanently reversed with certain natural supplements or extreme diets.
B: Yes, by eating much less sugar, you can get rid of it completely.
C: Type 2 diabetes cannot be cured; you must learn to live with it.
D: It's a temporary disease that disappears with age if you are careful.

Question: WHAT IS THE IMPACT OF ANOTHER ILLNESS ON A PERSON WITH DIABETES?
A: Another illness has no impact on diabetes, as they are independent of each other.
B: Another illness can worsen diabetes. Monitor your blood sugar and consult your doctor.
C: Any other illness will automatically make diabetes much easier to manage.
D: Having another illness protects a person with diabetes, as the body focuses on the new illness.

Question: WHY DO I KEEP GOING TO THE TOILET EVERY HOUR? WHY AM I ALWAYS TIRED?
A: It's just a sign that you are very stressed right now.
B: Frequent urination and fatigue can be due to various causes, including diabetes. Consult your doctor for an accurate diagnosis.
C: It's normal to have these symptoms with age."
D: You probably drank too much water before sleeping.

Question: Will diabetes be TRANSMITTED TO MY CHILDREN?
A: Diabetes is a disease of older people, so children cannot catch it.
B: Diabetes is caused by excessive sugar consumption, so if parents eat too much sugar, children will get it too.
C: Diabetes is like a cold; it can be transmitted through close contact.
D: Genetics play an important role in the transmission of diabetes.

Question: HOW WELL AM I MANAGING MY DIABETES?
A: Managing your diabetes well involves medication, sugar monitoring, a healthy diet, exercise, blood pressure/cholesterol control, quitting smoking, and foot care.
B: You are managing your diabetes well if you never eat sugar.
C: You are managing your diabetes well if you avoid carbohydrates at all costs.
D: You are managing your diabetes well if you don't feel sick.

Question: DOES DIABETES HAVE A LIFESPAN?
A: Diabetes is a chronic disease with no lifespan, requiring lifelong treatment.
B: Yes, diabetes has a "duration" of a few years, then it becomes less severe.
C: Yes, diabetes can be cured with strong medications for a certain period.
D: Yes, diabetes disappears after a few years if you follow a strict diet.

Question: HOW OFTEN SHOULD I MEASURE MY BLOOD SUGAR?
A: I must measure my blood sugar always at the same time each day, regardless of meals or activities.
B: Measure your blood sugar before and after each meal, and more often if necessary (exercise, feeling unwell, etc.). Consult your doctor for a personalized plan.
C: Once a week is enough, as diabetes doesn't change much from day to day.
D: It is not necessary to measure your blood sugar if you feel well; only a doctor can do it with a blood test.

Question: WHEN MY BLOOD SUGAR LEVEL IS HIGH, SHOULD I TAKE INSULIN TO LOWER IT?
A: Just eating less will make your blood sugar level go down on its own.
B: If you are a diabetic on insulin, yes. Otherwise, a healthy diet, exercise, and stress management help lower blood sugar.
C: You should drink lots of sugary water to balance the sugar in your blood.
D: Taking a heart pill will help lower your blood sugar level.

Question: IS SUGAR STRICTLY FORBIDDEN OR ALLOWED IN MODERATION?
A: Only natural sugars like honey and fruits are allowed; white sugar is strictly forbidden.
B: Diabetics can eat as much sugar as they want as long as they take their medication on time.
C: Sugar is not forbidden, but to be consumed in moderation, prioritizing sugars with a low glycemic index and limiting added sugars.
D: Sugar is completely forbidden for diabetics to avoid any increase in blood sugar level.

Question: how to UNDERSTAND CARBOHYDRATE INTAKE VERSUS INSULIN DOSE?
A: The number of carbohydrates doesn't really matter as long as you exercise regularly.
B: You just need to feel if you need more insulin after a meal based on how you feel.
C: Understanding the insulin-to-carb ratio and adjusting insulin dose based on fasting blood sugar is essential for managing carbohydrate intake.
D: You just need to take the same amount of insulin every day, regardless of what you eat.

Question: WHY DO SOME DIABETIC PATIENTS REQUIRE AMPUTATION?
A: It's because sugar in the blood eats away at the bones and muscles, making them too weak to support the body.
B: It's the only way to stop diabetes from spreading throughout the body.
C: It's a side effect of certain diabetes medications that can damage tissues.
D: Amputation in diabetics is due to poor circulation or sensation in the legs, causing non-healing wounds that become infected.

Question: I WOULD LIKE TO KNOW THE DO'S AND DON'TS IN THE AREA OF DIET for a diabetic?
A: Eat a balanced diet, rich in fiber and omega-3 (vegetables, whole grains, fish). Limit sugar, salt, fat. 3 regular meals.
B: Eating lots of fruit is always good for diabetics, regardless of the type or quantity.
C: Diabetics should only eat low-sugar foods, even if that means eliminating entire food groups.
D: It is better for diabetics to eat one or two large meals a day to control their blood sugar.

Question: WHERE ON MY BODY CAN I GIVE MYSELF INJECTIONS?
A: Inject into the arm, thigh, or abdomen, where there is fat under the skin.
B: Only in the veins, like for blood draws.
C: Anywhere, as long as the needle goes in.
D: Only in the muscle, so the medication acts quickly.

Question: WHAT ARE THE COMPLICATIONS THAT DIABETES CAN CAUSE?
A: Diabetes can lead to eye, kidney, nerve, and cardiovascular complications.
B: Diabetes weakens your bones and causes severe arthritis.
C: Diabetes can cause constant headaches and make you lose weight quickly.
D: Diabetes always causes skin rashes and makes your hair gray prematurely.

Question: Under what circumstances should diabetics inject insulin?
A: Diabetics inject insulin when their blood sugar is too high, especially type 1 diabetics.
B: Diabetics should only inject insulin if they have eaten a lot of sugar during the day.
C: Diabetics must inject insulin every morning on an empty stomach, regardless of their blood sugar level.
D: Diabetics should only inject insulin if they feel tired or weak.

Question: Is diabetes a disease that can be overcome, or once a person has it, do they have it for life?
A: Diabetes is a chronic disease that is not cured, but can be treated and controlled.
B: Type 2 diabetes can be completely cured with a strict diet and exercise.
C: Diabetes is only temporary and generally disappears with age.
D: Type 1 diabetes can be cured with herbal treatments.

Question: What kind of special diet should a person with diabetes follow, and are there foods they cannot consume at all?
A: A strict sugar-free diet is mandatory, and they absolutely cannot eat anything containing sugar, even naturally.
B: Prioritize a balanced diet, rich in fiber and healthy fats, limiting sugars and fats. No food is forbidden, but some should be consumed in moderation to stabilize blood sugar.
C: They must eat mainly lean protein and avoid all carbohydrates, including fruits and vegetables.
D: A precise and identical diet must be followed for all diabetics, completely eliminating fats.

Question: Under what circumstances is a ketogenic diet an effective treatment FOR diabetics?
A: When it helps with rapid weight loss, which is good for diabetes.
B: Not recommended for diabetics.
C: When the diabetic wants to reduce their dependence on medication.
D: If the diabetic has difficulty controlling their blood sugar with other diets.

Question: What are the first symptoms of diabetes?
A: Generalized muscle and joint pain.
B: Dizziness and nausea after meals.
C: Fever and chills, like during the flu.
D: Fatigue, intense thirst, frequent urge to urinate, weight loss, blurred vision, slow wound healing, and recurrent infections can be the first symptoms of diabetes.

Question: How can one contract diabetes so late in life? Does eating a lot of sweets cause diabetes?
A: Eating too many carbohydrates, not just sweets, is the only cause of diabetes.
B: Late-onset diabetes is caused by stress and lack of sleep that exhaust the body.
C: Late-onset diabetes is linked to genetics, lifestyle, or illnesses. Eating too much sugar is not the direct cause but promotes insulin resistance.
D: Late-onset diabetes simply happens with age, it's a normal part of aging.

Question: Besides candy and other foods high in sugar, what foods should diabetics avoid?
A: Foods without added sugar, because they contain dangerous artificial sweeteners.
B: Water, because it dilutes insulin in the blood.
C: Leafy green vegetables, because they are very sugary.
D: Avoid white bread/rice/pasta, refined cereals, syrupy fruits, processed meats, cheese, butter, fatty meats.

Question: On what part of the body do diabetics inject insulin?
A: Diabetics inject insulin under the skin (abdomen, thighs, arms, buttocks) with a pen, syringe, or pump.
B: Diabetics inject insulin directly into their veins so it acts faster.
C: Insulin is a medication that is applied to the skin like a cream.
D: Insulin is taken by mouth because it is less painful than an injection.

Question: Does cholesterol play a role in the diagnosis of diabetes?
A: Cholesterol is an important cardiovascular risk factor in diabetes, with specific target levels for LDL and HDL.
B: Cholesterol has no link with diabetes; they are two completely different diseases.
C: High cholesterol level means the body produces too much insulin, which is a sign of diabetes.
D: Cholesterol is the main culprit for diabetes, so its high level confirms the diagnosis.

Question: What is it about obesity that makes one more vulnerable to type 2 diabetes?
A: Obesity slows down blood circulation, which prevents the body from using sugar properly.
B: Fat cells absorb all the sugar, leaving not enough for the body, causing diabetes.
C: Excess weight forces the pancreas to produce too much sugar, which causes diabetes.
D: Obesity, especially abdominal obesity, causes insulin resistance, making the body less effective at regulating blood sugar and increasing the risk of type 2 diabetes.

Question: To what extent will you have to change your lifestyle to deal with diabetes?
A: The only necessary change is to take insulin injections every day.
B: Diabetes is not a serious illness and does not require significant lifestyle changes.
C: Adopt a healthy diet, exercise, quit smoking/drinking, and follow your treatment to manage diabetes and prevent complications.
D: You can continue to eat and drink whatever you want, as long as you take your medication.

Question: Can a change in diet prevent the onset of diabetes in someone genetically predisposed to contracting it?
A: Yes, if you remove all sugar from your diet, diabetes will not develop.
B: No, genetics is the only determining factor and diet has no influence.
C: Diabetes can only be prevented by medication, not by a change in diet.
D: Yes, a healthy diet and exercise can reduce the risk of diabetes, even with a genetic predisposition.

Question: What role does increased fat mass play in increasing the risk of diabetes?
A: Having more fat makes the body less efficient at burning calories, which forces the pancreas to produce too much insulin and exhausts it.
B: Excess fat, especially abdominal fat, causes insulin resistance, increasing blood glucose and the risk of diabetes.
C: Fat blocks blood circulation, which prevents sugar from reaching muscles to be used and causes it to build up in the blood.
D: Increased fat mass slows down digestion, causing sugar to stay in the blood longer and increasing the risk of diabetes.

Question: What is the average weight of a person diagnosed with type 2 diabetes?
A: Average weight varies, but abdominal obesity is a risk. Losing 5-10% of weight improves blood sugar, through a balanced diet and exercise.
B: Average weight is difficult to determine, but it is likely similar to that of the general population.
C: People with type 2 diabetes are always overweight or obese, so their average weight is very high.
D: People with type 2 diabetes are often thin, as their body cannot store fat properly, so their average weight is low.

Question: What types of food should people with type 2 diabetes avoid?
A: People with type 2 diabetes should avoid eating proteins like meat and eggs, as this can affect their blood sugar.
B: Avoid added sugars, saturated fats, and white flour to control blood sugar and heart risks.
C: People with type 2 diabetes should avoid eating starchy vegetables like potatoes, as they are bad for blood sugar.
D: People with type 2 diabetes must avoid all fruits because they contain a lot of natural sugar.

Question: What preventive measures should be taken if your family is known to have diabetes?
A: Eating lots of fruits and vegetables without worrying about the rest of your diet protects against diabetes.
B: Getting vaccinated against diabetes completely prevents the disease.
C: Drinking sugar-free sodas instead of regular sodas is enough to prevent diabetes.
D: Adopt a healthy diet, exercise, maintain a healthy weight, and monitor your blood sugar to prevent diabetes if you have a family history.

Question: If I contract diabetes, is it true that I can fight it with an excellent diet instead of taking medication?
A: A good diet can replace insulin for type 1 diabetes.
B: Only carbohydrates are important to control in the diet to manage diabetes.
C: Yes, a strict diet can completely cure diabetes, making medication unnecessary.
D: Diet alone is not enough to fight type 2 diabetes; it often requires medication, exercise, and medical follow-up.

Question: Can surgery be performed to "repair" the cause of diabetes?
A: Pancreatic cell transplantation can "repair" the cause of diabetes, but it is experimental and carries risks.
B: Yes, the part of the pancreas that is not working well can be removed to cure diabetes.
C: No, diabetes is caused by sugar and surgery cannot change that.
D: Yes, the liver can be operated on because it controls blood sugar.

Question: Is there a symptom or group of symptoms that a person can experience very early on that announces the onset of diabetes?
A: Yes, the only early sign of diabetes is a sensation of intense cold and unexplained trembling.
B: Yes, a persistent metallic taste in the mouth is a sure sign of the onset of diabetes.
C: Fatigue, intense thirst, frequent urination, weight loss, blurred vision, or infections can signal diabetes.
D: No, diabetes has no symptoms at the beginning; it is always discovered by chance during a routine examination.

Question: How has daily maintenance, blood sugar checks, and medication administration changed for diabetics over the past ten years?
A: Diabetics can now eat whatever they want as long as they take their medication.
B: Diabetics no longer need to check their blood sugar as often thanks to new medications.
C: Diabetes care has evolved with technology (pumps, sensors) and new recommendations for better management.
D: Diabetes medications are now all in pill form, so injections are no longer necessary.

Question: What is the life expectancy of a person with type 2 diabetes?
A: People with type 2 diabetes generally live the same lifespan as others.
B: Type 2 diabetes can reduce life expectancy by about 10 years, but a healthy lifestyle and good control can improve it.
C: Type 2 diabetes shortens life by only one or two years at most.
D: Type 2 diabetes has no significant impact on life expectancy if one takes their medication.

Question: My mother has type 2 diabetes. Does this increase my risk?
A: Yes, type 2 diabetes has a significant family factor. The risk is about 40% if one parent is affected, and 70% if both are.
B: Yes, but only if you eat the same things as your mother.
C: No, diabetes is caused by a poor diet, not by genetics.
D: No, type 2 diabetes is a disease that affects only older people, not young people.

Question: Can diabetes affect a person's mood? What are the first symptoms of diabetes?
A: Diabetes affects mood, but the initial symptoms are only thirst and fatigue.
B: Yes, diabetes affects mood (irritability, anxiety) and initial symptoms include excessive thirst, fatigue, and frequent urination.
C: No, diabetes does not affect mood; it's a purely physical disease related to sugar.
D: Yes, diabetes always makes people sad and the initial symptoms are constant hunger.

Question: Can type II diabetes be reversed or cured, for example, by changing one's diet and becoming healthier?
A: No, once you have type 2 diabetes, there is absolutely nothing you can do to improve your condition.
B: Yes, just follow a strict diet for a few months to get rid of it permanently.
C: Type 2 diabetes cannot be cured, but controlled by a healthy lifestyle (diet, exercise) and medication to avoid complications.
D: Yes, if you stop eating sugar completely, your pancreas will function normally again.

Question: Have new medications to treat diabetes been approved in recent years?
A: Yes, new medications like tirzepatide, PATAS and linagliptin have been approved, offering new options for type 2 diabetes.
B: Yes, but only for type 1 diabetes; treatments for type 2 are the same as before.
C: Yes, but these are mainly natural remedies or food supplements that have been approved, not real medications.
D: No, diabetes treatments haven't changed much in years; insulin and old pills are still used.

Question: I know that physical exercise can be beneficial for diabetes, but are there specific exercises that yield better results?
A: Just doing light movements with the arms and legs for a few minutes each day is enough.
B: Only very intense exercise like running a marathon can truly help control diabetes.
C: 30 mins/day of moderate to intense activity (walking, swimming, strength training) is beneficial for diabetes. Adapt to your level and treatment.
D: Physical exercise is only beneficial for diabetes if you lose a lot of weight quickly.

Question: Can a low-carbohydrate diet reverse the course of type 2 diabetes?
A: Yes, a low-carbohydrate diet reverses type 2 diabetes very quickly, usually within a few days, and people can then return to a normal diet without risk.
B: Yes, a low-carbohydrate diet definitively cures type 2 diabetes by completely eliminating the need for insulin and medication.
C: A low-carbohydrate diet can help some diabetics lower their blood sugar, but consult a doctor before adopting it.
D: No, a low-carbohydrate diet has no impact on type 2 diabetes, as the problem is related to the body's inability to produce insulin, not to carbohydrate consumption.

Question: Does prediabetes always turn into diabetes?
A: No, prediabetes does not always progress to diabetes. A healthy lifestyle can prevent or delay its onset.
B: Yes, once you have prediabetes, there is nothing you can do to stop it.
C: Yes, prediabetes is just another name for early-stage diabetes.
D: No, prediabetes is just a temporary problem that goes away on its own.

Question: Is type 2 diabetes hereditary or related to diet?
A: Type 2 diabetes is a disease that you only catch by eating too much sugar, like a virus.
B: Type 2 diabetes is primarily linked to lifestyle (diet, physical activity), with a genetic predisposition.
C: Type 2 diabetes is solely linked to a lack of insulin and has nothing to do with weight.
D: Type 2 diabetes is a disease that affects only older people and is unavoidable.

Question: Is diabetes a genetic disease that makes some people more likely to contract it?
A: No, diabetes is solely caused by excessive sugar consumption, regardless of your family history.
B: Yes, diabetes is entirely determined by your genes and you cannot do anything to prevent it.
C: Diabetes is a viral infection that you catch by being in contact with a sick person.
D: Diabetes is not always genetic, but a predisposition exists, especially for type 1. Type 2 is linked to lifestyle.

Question: What can be done to prevent diabetes and are preventive measures effective?
A: Adopting a healthy lifestyle (diet, exercise, weight, quitting smoking/alcohol) prevents type 2 diabetes. Gestational diabetes is prevented by medical follow-up. Type 1 is not preventable.
B: Diabetes is hereditary and cannot be prevented by lifestyle changes.
C: Taking specific vitamin supplements can prevent diabetes.
D: Eating a lot of sugar during childhood protects against diabetes in adulthood.

Question: How has diabetes treatment progressed in recent years?
A: A vaccine has been found that prevents diabetes from appearing; we no longer have to worry about it.
B: Diabetes is now completely cured thanks to new pills; insulin is no longer needed.
C: Diabetes is no longer a serious problem because there are surgeries that cure it easily.
D: Diabetes treatment has progressed with insulin, better blood sugar controls, new medications and technologies, but the disease is still increasing.

Question: What are the causes of diabetes?
A: Diabetes is solely caused by lack of exercise.
B: Diabetes is caused by a virus caught in childhood.
C: Eating too much sugar directly causes diabetes.
D: Diabetes is an excess of sugar in the blood. Type 1 is autoimmune, type 2 is lifestyle-related, and gestational occurs during pregnancy.

Question: What needs to be done to cure diabetes?
A: A daily insulin injection is enough to completely cure diabetes.
B: Type 2 diabetes is not cured, but a healthy lifestyle and treatments can control it.
C: There are natural herbal remedies that can permanently cure diabetes.
D: Diabetes disappears naturally with age or after a period of prolonged fasting.

Question: how does it manifest? gangrene?
A: It makes your skin turn yellow like jaundice.
B: Gangrene manifests as stiffness, swelling, loss of sensation, pain, blisters/ulcers, and cold/pale skin.
C: It's when your leg feels numb and tingly for a little while.
D: It's just a bad smell in your foot that goes away with washing.

Question: Can a pancreas transplant cure diabetes?
A: No, a pancreas transplant only slows down the progression of diabetes; it never cures it.
B: Yes, a pancreas transplant is a simple surgery that cures all types of diabetes and has no risks.
C: A pancreas transplant can cure diabetes, but only if the person follows a very strict diet for the rest of their life.
D: Yes, a pancreas transplant can cure type 1 diabetes, but it is reserved for unstable cases or those with end-stage renal failure.

Question: What will your diet be like if you have diabetes?
A: Eat balanced meals, limit sugars/fats/salt, prioritize fiber/fish/turmeric/olive oil, drink water.
B: Eat only fruits because natural sugar is better for your body.
C: Completely eliminate all carbohydrates from your diet to control blood sugar.
D: Drink only "diet" drinks because they don't contain sugar.

Question: Do you ever no longer have to prick your finger to measure your blood sugar?
A: Yes, if diabetes is controlled by medication.
B: Yes, some diabetics use continuous sensors to measure their blood sugar without fingersticks.
C: Yes, if you have a very strict diet.
D: Yes, it's possible if you eat very little sugar.

Question: What is the most difficult aspect of diabetes?
A: Diabetes is only a problem for elderly people and does not affect young people.
B: Eating a lot of sugar occasionally has no impact on diabetes if you take medication.
C: Diabetes can be cured by taking vitamins or natural remedies.
D: The most difficult aspect of diabetes varies by person, often related to treatment constraints, symptoms, or fears of complications.

Question: How does diabetes affect a person's daily life and activities?
A: Diabetes only affects what you eat; you can live normally as long as you avoid sugar.
B: Diabetes is a disease that disappears if you lose enough weight.
C: Diabetes makes people so tired they can never exercise or go out again.
D: Diabetes requires blood sugar monitoring, diet, exercise, and can cause complications affecting daily life, work, and relationships.

Question: With age, does diabetes become more troublesome and difficult to treat?
A: Yes, diabetes can become more difficult to treat with age, increasing the risk of complications.
B: Yes, but only because blood sugar tests become less accurate as you age.
C: Age has no impact on diabetes treatment; it's the initial severity that matters.
D: No, the body becomes more resistant with age and manages diabetes better.

Question: I understand that two fasting values over 1.26g/dL trigger a diagnosis of type II diabetes, but will a doctor automatically put a patient on medication at this stage, or will they still give them a chance to lower these levels through diet and/or physical exercise?
A: The doctor may treat diabetes immediately or after a trial of diet/exercise to prevent complications.
B: The doctor will always first ask the patient to diet and exercise for several months before considering medication.
C: The doctor will always immediately start a very strong medication treatment to avoid complications, as diabetes is very dangerous.
D: At this stage, the patient does not yet have diabetes; it's just prediabetes, so no treatment is needed.

Question: I've read that type II diabetes can sometimes be reversed through substantial changes in diet and exercise habits. Is this true?
A: Yes, type 2 diabetes can be reduced or reversed through a healthy diet and exercise, improving insulin sensitivity and blood sugar.
B: It's a myth; diet and exercise only help manage symptoms.
C: Only if you take very expensive medication at the same time.
D: No, once you have diabetes, you have it forever and nothing can change it.

Question: If I have been diagnosed with prediabetes, can I avoid full-blown diabetes by adopting good eating habits and exercising?
A: No, once you have prediabetes, full-blown diabetes is inevitable and lifestyle changes cannot stop it.
B: Yes, but only if your prediabetes is very mild; if your sugar levels are already a bit high, it's too late to reverse it.
C: Yes, you can avoid diabetes by adopting good eating habits and exercising. Prediabetes is reversible with lifestyle changes.
D: Maybe, but only if you start taking medication right away, as diet and exercise alone are not enough.

Question: What can we do, as a community, to combat diabetes and stem its spread?
A: Diabetes is genetic, so there is nothing we can do as a community to stop it.
B: We can wait for researchers to find a miracle cure, because prevention is too difficult for everyone.
C: Raise awareness, encourage healthy activity/eating, screen early, and support people with diabetes to combat it.
D: People with diabetes should simply stop eating sugar, and the problem will be solved for everyone.

Question: What are the most important lifestyle changes for someone newly diagnosed with diabetes?
A: Replace all meals with special diabetic meal replacements sold in pharmacies.
B: Adopt a healthy diet, exercise, monitor your blood sugar, and follow medical advice to manage your diabetes.
C: Completely avoid exercise, as it could cause dangerously low blood sugar.
D: Eat fewer carbohydrates forever, even good carbohydrates like fruits and vegetables.

Question: Can diabetes be prevented from a young age?
A: Yes, by completely avoiding sugar in all its forms from birth.
B: Yes, by taking specific vitamins from childhood to strengthen the pancreas.
C: No, diabetes is a genetic disease that inevitably develops if your parents had it.
D: Preventing type 2 diabetes from a young age is possible through a healthy lifestyle: ideal weight, physical activity, balanced diet, no smoking.

Question: What are the ways to know if you have diabetes?
A: You just need to check if you are losing weight without trying to know if you are diabetic.
B: A doctor diagnoses diabetes through a blood test (fasting blood sugar â‰¥ 1.26 g/l or 7 mmol/l, twice).
C: A urine test sold in pharmacies can confirm if you have diabetes.
D: You can tell if you have diabetes by seeing if you are thirstier more often or if you eat a lot.

Question: Does "adult-onset diabetes" really exist? Can you become diabetic simply by gaining too much weight?
A: Adult-onset diabetes is type 1 diabetes that appears later in life.
B: No, adult-onset diabetes is an old term that is no longer used because all types of diabetes are similar.
C: You can't become diabetic just by gaining weight; you also need to eat a lot of sugar.
D: "Adult-onset diabetes" is type 2 diabetes, often linked to overweight and lifestyle, but not only.

Question: If adult-onset diabetes is a reality, can you get rid of diabetes by losing weight, for example?
A: Losing weight improves type 2 diabetes control but does not cure it; medical follow-up and a healthy lifestyle remain essential.
B: Adult-onset diabetes is caused solely by overweight, so by losing weight, the disease disappears.
C: Losing weight means you can eat whatever you want without worrying about your blood sugar.
D: Yes, losing a lot of weight completely eliminates diabetes and you no longer need treatment.

Question: What are the first symptoms of diabetes?
A: Intense muscle pain and increased sensitivity to cold are early signs of diabetes.
B: The first visible symptom is a red and scaly skin rash on the arms and legs.
C: A strong urge to eat sweets for no reason is a sign that your body is not managing sugar well.
D: Type 1 diabetes: intense thirst, frequent urination, weight loss. Type 2: often subtle, fatigue, moderate thirst. Diagnosis by blood test.

Question: What is the most important step one can take to avoid becoming diabetic?
A: Avoiding all contact with people who already have diabetes, as it is a contagious disease.
B: Drinking lots of sugary water to help the body regulate blood sugar.
C: Adopting a healthy diet, exercising regularly, and monitoring your weight are the keys to preventing type 2 diabetes.
D: Taking over-the-counter vitamins every day to strengthen the pancreas.

Question: Does a person with diabetes live shorter than a non-diabetic person?
A: The life expectancy of people with diabetes is only slightly lower, by a few years at most.
B: Diabetes has no significant impact on life expectancy if one is careful about their diet.
C: On average, diabetes reduces life expectancy by 10 years, but good control allows living as long as a non-diabetic.
D: A person with diabetes generally lives the same lifespan as a non-diabetic person.

Question: Can the symptoms of type 2 diabetes be minimized, or completely cured, solely by changing lifestyle?
A: Only medication can truly treat type 2 diabetes; lifestyle changes have no significant impact.
B: Changing lifestyle can minimize the symptoms of type 2 diabetes, but not completely cure it.
C: Yes, type 2 diabetes is a benign disease that completely disappears with diet and exercise.
D: No, type 2 diabetes always requires insulin injections, regardless of your lifestyle.

Question: How to manage genetic risk factors for type 2 diabetes?
A: Manage genetic risks for type 2 diabetes through regular screening and a healthy lifestyle (weight, exercise, diet, no smoking/alcohol).
B: You can modify your genes through specific diets or supplements.
C: Genetic factors mean that you will develop diabetes no matter what, so lifestyle changes are useless.
D: There is nothing to be done for genetic risks, so management is not possible.

Question: What are the most important changes to make to the lifestyle of a type 2 diabetic?
A: Weight loss, regular physical activity, and a balanced diet are key to managing type 2 diabetes.
B: Only insulin injections are effective in managing type 2 diabetes.
C: People with type 2 diabetes must avoid all sugar, including fruits.
D: Just taking medication is enough to control type 2 diabetes.

Question: My mother had complete liver failure not too long ago, and she was diagnosed with type II diabetes about 10 years ago. Could the liver failure have been caused by diabetes?
A: Yes, type 2 diabetes can cause liver failure through insulin resistance, leading to steatosis or cirrhosis.
B: No, diabetes only affects the pancreas and heart, not the liver.
C: Yes, diabetes overloads the liver with sugar, causing it to fail.
D: Diabetes slows down blood circulation, which can damage the liver over time.

Question: Is it possible that type II diabetes is actually type I diabetes that hasn't been diagnosed for decades?
A: No, type 2 and type 1 diabetes are distinct. Type 1 is autoimmune with insulin deficiency; type 2 is linked to insulin resistance and develops slowly.
B: It's possible if the pancreas was still producing a little insulin for years before stopping.
C: Yes, type II diabetes can be undiagnosed type I for a long time because the symptoms are similar.
D: It depends on the severity; if type I diabetes is very mild, it can resemble type II at first.

Question: Can type II diabetes be completely cured?
A: Type 2 diabetes goes away on its own over time if you eat less sugar.
B: Type 2 diabetes can be cured with natural remedies like herbs or supplements.
C: Type 2 diabetes is not cured, but lasting remission is possible with lifestyle changes, especially if action is taken early.
D: Yes, type 2 diabetes can be cured by taking medication every day.

Question: Does being diabetic mean I am more exposed to other medical problems?
A: Only if I take insulin, as insulin has many side effects.
B: Maybe, but only if I eat a lot of sugar or if I am overweight.
C: No, diabetes is just a blood sugar problem; it doesn't affect other parts of the body.
D: Yes, poorly controlled diabetes increases the risk of acute and chronic complications, affecting heart, kidneys, eyes, nerves, and more.

Question: How often should I measure my blood sugar and what should I do if it is too high or too low?
A: Measure blood sugar according to your type of diabetes. In case of hypoglycemia, consume fast-acting carbohydrates. In case of hyperglycemia, identify the cause and consult your healthcare team.
B: I must always measure my blood sugar before each meal, and if it's too high, I can simply drink a lot of water to lower it.
C: I can measure my blood sugar once a week if I feel well, and I don't need to do anything if it's a bit high or low.
D: Measurement frequency does not depend on the type of diabetes, and if my blood sugar is too low, I must take more insulin.

Question: Are there any new medications that I could use to manage my diabetes?
A: There is a new cream to apply to the skin that lowers blood sugar instantly.
B: Yes, there are new pills that can completely cure diabetes; you just need to take one a day.
C: New injectable medications for type 2 diabetes are in development, improving insulin, weight, and blood sugar.
D: They have developed a very strict new diet that replaces the need for diabetes medication.

Question: Does diabetes always lead to limb complications with age?
A: Diabetes increases the risk of lower limb arterial disease, but good blood sugar control can prevent these complications.
B: Diabetes weakens the leg muscles, leading to difficulty walking with age.
C: No, limb complications only affect people with type 1 diabetes.
D: Yes, diabetes always causes circulation problems that require leg amputation over time.

Question: Does diabetes directly cause or increase the risk of other serious diseases?
A: Diabetes only affects blood sugar; it has no impact on other organs in the body.
B: Yes, diabetes increases the risk of heart, kidney, nerve, and eye diseases by damaging blood vessels.
C: Diabetes is only dangerous if you eat a lot of sugar; otherwise, there is no risk of complications.
D: Diabetes does not cause serious illnesses; it just makes people more tired.

Question: Is there a genetic predisposition to diabetes? Or is it purely a matter of diet?
A: Diabetes is always caused by a poor diet; genetics plays no role.
B: Yes, there is a genetic predisposition to type 2 diabetes, but diet and lifestyle also play a major role.
C: Diabetes is purely a hereditary disease; the way you live has no influence.
D: Only obese people can develop diabetes, so genetics is irrelevant.

Question: Will diabetes one day be "cured"?
A: There is already a vaccine that cures type 1 diabetes.
B: Yes, most cases of diabetes can be cured with natural remedies or food supplements.
C: Diabetes is chronic, not curable but controllable. Weight loss can reverse type 2, but the disease persists.
D: Diabetes generally disappears on its own after a few years if you are careful about your diet.

Question: Are there any natural remedies for diabetes that have shown promise?
A: Eating a lot of sugar can cure diabetes by getting the body used to large amounts.
B: Drinking only water and fresh fruit juices can reverse diabetes.
C: Some plants like berberine, cinnamon, or turmeric show potential to help manage blood sugar, but medical follow-up remains essential.
D: Diabetes can be cured by completely stopping eating for a few days.

Question: Is diabetes curable? In other words, can one get rid of diabetes completely without any lingering effects? Or is it a disease that one must live with?
A: Diabetes is completely cured with medicinal plants and natural remedies.
B: Diabetes is generally not curable, but it can be effectively controlled through treatment and lifestyle.
C: Diabetes is not a real disease; it's just a blood sugar problem that is easily fixed.
D: Yes, you just need to eat less sugar and diabetes disappears.

Question: Are there ways to know if you are predisposed to diabetes even if you don't know if your family has a history of diabetes?
A: You just need to do a urine test at home to see if there is sugar in it.
B: If you eat a lot of sugar and don't gain weight, it means you are predisposed.
C: Consult your doctor for blood tests (fasting blood sugar, HbA1c) to confirm diabetes. Symptoms and risk factors (age, overweight) can alert you.
D: You can tell by seeing if you have a lot of freckles, as this is a genetic sign.

Question: What are the best ways to prevent diabetes?
A: Drinking a lot of sugary water to dilute the sugar in the blood.
B: Prevent diabetes through physical activity, weight loss, balanced diet (low GI, fruits/vegetables, fish), quitting smoking, and regular blood sugar monitoring.
C: Avoiding eating altogether to avoid increasing your blood sugar.
D: Taking special vitamins sold in pharmacies that block sugar absorption.

Question: Are there variations in the severity of diabetes and what determines the severity?
A: No, diabetes is always the same serious disease for everyone.
B: The severity of diabetes is the same for everyone, but the symptoms vary.
C: The severity of diabetes varies depending on the type, blood sugar, complications, and individual factors like age and lifestyle.
D: The severity of diabetes depends solely on the amount of sugar you eat.

Question: Is diabetes genetic and what is the probability of a child getting it if one parent has it?
A: Diabetes is genetic. The risk for the child is 5% for type 1 and up to 70% for type 2 if both parents are affected.
B: The probability is the same for all types of diabetes, about 50%, because it's fifty-fifty.
C: Yes, diabetes is always genetic, so the child will surely get it if a parent has it.
D: No, diabetes is not genetic; it is solely caused by a poor diet.

Question: What are the main differences in severity and symptoms between type 1 and type 2 diabetes?
A: The main difference is that type 1 diabetes always requires insulin injections, while type 2 can be controlled by diet alone.
B: Type 1 diabetes is simply a more severe version of type 2 diabetes, appearing earlier in life.
C: Type 1: autoimmune, young people, sudden symptoms, insulin. Type 2: resistance, elderly/overweight, asymptomatic/complications, hygiene/medication.
D: Type 2 diabetes is caused by excessive sugar consumption, while type 1 is a genetic disease.

Question: What can I do to avoid getting either type of diabetes and what symptoms should I watch out for?
A: You just need to eat less sugar and you won't get it; the symptoms are just severe fatigue.
B: Healthy lifestyle (diet, exercise, stress, smoking) and weight/blood sugar control prevent diabetes. Symptoms: thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, weight loss, infections, blurry visio...
C: You need to eat a lot of fruits and vegetables and avoid intense sport; the symptoms are being very hungry all the time.
D: Diabetes is genetic; there's nothing you can do to avoid it; you just need to be careful when you feel weak.

Question: COULD INSULIN AFFECT MY SKIN?
A: Yes, insulin can make the skin dry and flaky all over the body.
B: No, insulin only affects blood sugar, not the skin.
C: Insulin makes the skin more sensitive to the sun and sunburn.
D: Yes, insulin can affect the skin (dents/lumps). Change your needle and examine your skin regularly.

Question: Can insulin injections CAUSE SKIN RASHES?
A: No, insulin is a natural medication produced by the body so it cannot cause reactions.
B: Only if you are allergic to mosquito bites, as the needle is similar.
C: Yes, if you don't disinfect your skin with strong alcohol before injecting.
D: Yes, insulin injections can cause skin rashes (allergy, infection, etc.). Change the site and consult a doctor if persistent.

Question: Can insulin injections CAUSE ALLERGIES TO VARIOUS PRODUCTS?
A: Insulin can cause local/generalized allergies, but not directly to other products.
B: Yes, insulin modifies the immune system, making people more sensitive to food allergies.
C: Yes, insulin contains traces of many known allergens that can cause reactions to other products.
D: No, insulin has no link with allergies to other products; it is diabetes itself that causes allergies.

Question: WHAT CAN HELP MY DIABETES?
A: Drinking diet sodas to compensate for sugars.
B: Follow your doctor's advice, take your medication, monitor your blood sugar, eat healthily, and exercise.
C: Completely avoiding carbohydrates, even those that are good for your health.
D: Eating a lot of sugar so your body gets used to it and stops reacting.

Question: HOW TO EASILY MANAGE BLOOD SUGAR?
A: Manage your blood sugar by monitoring it, eating balanced meals (less sugar/fat, more fiber/complex carbohydrates), drinking water, and exercising.
B: Eat less so the body doesn't need to produce as much sugar.
C: Take heart medication because diabetes affects the heart.
D: Drink sugary drinks because sugar helps balance sugar in the blood.

Question: Why does my blood sugar increase DESPITE ADEQUATE INSULIN INTAKE?
A: Your body is getting used to insulin and needs more to function.
B: Your blood sugar can increase despite insulin due to diet, stress, infection, or medications. Consult a doctor if hyperglycemia persists.
C: The insulin is expired or of poor quality, making it ineffective.
D: You ate too much sugar the day before, and it still affects your blood sugar.

Question: Why does my blood sugar increase DESPITE a BALANCED DIET?
A: Drinking sugary water unknowingly in "sugar-free" drinks can be the cause.
B: Skipping meals causes the body to store more sugar when you eat.
C: Eating too much fruit, even healthy fruit, can raise blood sugar.
D: Your blood sugar may increase despite a balanced diet due to lack of insulin, stress, infection, or certain medications. Consult your doctor.

Question: IN THE FUTURE, IS IT POSSIBLE TO CONSIDER A TREATMENT OTHER THAN INJECTION, FOR EXAMPLE INSULIN PATCHES?
A: Yes, insulin patches exist (approved patch pumps) and needle-free patches are being researched, but not yet available.
B: Insulin patches are in development but they cannot replace injections because they don't dose insulin correctly.
C: Yes, there are already insulin patches sold in pharmacies without a prescription, like patches for type 2 diabetes.
D: Insulin cannot pass through the skin, so patches will never be an option for administering insulin.

Question: WHY IS IT GETTING MORE AND MORE DIFFICULT TO CONTROL MY BLOOD SUGAR WITH AGE?
A: It's just normal for your body to slow down, like an old car.
B: Your blood sugar can increase with age due to factors like heredity, stress, sedentary lifestyle, and obesity, promoting type 2 diabetes.
C: Eating less sugar is no longer enough as you get older.
D: Your cells are becoming less good at using insulin because they are tired.

Question: Does taking other MEDICATIONS have an impact ON MY DIABETES CONTROL?
A: It depends on the color of the medication; red medications affect blood sugar levels more.
B: Only if the medications are for a heart condition, as the heart and diabetes are linked.
C: No, medications for other illnesses do not act on diabetes; they treat different problems in the body.
D: Yes, other medications can affect your blood sugar. Always consult your doctor before taking a new medication.

Question: MORE INFORMATION ABOUT DIET for people with diabetes?
A: People with diabetes must avoid all sugars, even those present in fruits.
B: A balanced diet, rich in fiber, antioxidants, and omega-3, with 3 regular meals, is key for diabetics. Prioritize vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, fatty fish, etc.
C: Eating only two large meals a day helps to better control blood sugar.
D: It is most important to eat "sugar-free" foods even if they are very fatty or salty.

Question: What is the EFFECT of diabetes on the EYES?
A: Diabetes can make the eyes shrink and cause blurry vision.
B: Diabetes discolors the eyes, making them yellow or red.
C: Diabetes can damage the retina, vitreous humor, or optic nerve, thus affecting vision.
D: Diabetes causes the eyes to swell and makes them more sensitive to light.

Question: ARE THERE NEW TREATMENTS AVAILABLE for diabetes?
A: The only new thing is insulin in pills, which replaces injections.
B: New treatments are limited to very strict diets designed by artificial intelligence.
C: Yes, new treatments include tirzepatide, bariatric surgery, artificial pancreas, Eversense sensor, and SGLT2 inhibitors.
D: There is now a vaccine that prevents diabetes.

Question: IS LIFESTYLE OR DIET THE MAIN FACTOR HELPING TREATMENT?
A: No, lifestyle has only a minor impact compared to genetics.
B: Yes, lifestyle and diet are essential for treating diabetes.
C: No, only regular physical exercise has a significant impact on treatment.
D: No, medication is the only way to effectively treat diabetes.

Question: How to manage WEIGHT PROBLEMS in people with diabetes?
A: Drinking a lot of "light" sugary drinks to replace meals.
B: Manage your weight by consulting your doctor, eating balanced meals (low in sugar/fat), and exercising regularly.
C: Taking laxatives regularly to help with digestion and weight loss.
D: Completely avoiding carbohydrates, even those from fruits and vegetables, to lose weight quickly.

Question: INSULIN PUMPS what is the benefit?
A: An insulin pump is a device that replaces the pancreas and cures diabetes.
B: An insulin pump delivers insulin continuously, improving blood sugar control and quality of life, especially if multiple injections are insufficient.
C: An insulin pump is a device that automatically injects insulin only during meals.
D: An insulin pump is a small device that measures blood sugar level.

Question: WILL THE SITUATION WORSEN over time for a person with diabetes?
A: Only if you don't eat any sugar at all, because the body needs it to function.
B: Yes, diabetes always gets worse over time, even if you are careful about your diet.
C: No, diabetes is a chronic illness but it does not necessarily worsen over time if you take your medication.
D: Yes, diabetes can worsen and cause complications if blood sugar is not controlled.

Question: WHAT IS AN ACCEPTABLE HBA1C AND DOES IT VARY FROM PATIENT TO PATIENT?
A: An acceptable HbA1c varies, but generally aims for <7% (53 mmol/mol) for diabetics and <6% (42 mmol/mol) for those at risk.
B: HbA1c measures blood sugar in real-time, like a traditional blood sugar meter.
C: HbA1c is only relevant for type 1 diabetes and not for type 2 diabetes.
D: HbA1c is always the same number for everyone, regardless of whether they have diabetes or not.

Question: CAN MEDICATIONS REPLACE insulin INJECTIONS?
A: No, medications do not replace insulin for type 1 diabetes. Type 2 may use oral medications.
B: Yes, medications can completely cure diabetes and eliminate the need for insulin.
C: Yes, if you eat well, you don't need insulin or medication.
D: Yes, pill medications are always more effective than insulin injections.

Question: SHOULD MY EXTENDED FAMILY BE TESTED REGULARLY for diabetes?
A: No, unless a family member shows signs of diabetes.
B: Yes, because everyone should be tested for diabetes every year, regardless of family history.
C: No, diabetes is caused by a poor diet, so if your family eats healthily, they don't need to be tested.
D: Yes, because diabetes is a very contagious disease and spreads easily within families.

Question: What can a person with diabetes eat?
A: Eat varied, limit sugar, watch portions and carbohydrates.
B: A person with diabetes can eat whatever they want as long as they take their medication.
C: A person with diabetes can only eat green vegetables and lean meat.
D: A person with diabetes must avoid all fruits because they contain sugar.

Question: Is it possible to RECEIVE INSULIN BY PUMP AS NEEDED, RATHER THAN HAVING TO DO INJECTIONS CONSTANTLY?
A: Insulin pumps are only for very severe cases of diabetes and are not common.
B: An insulin pump is just a device for measuring sugar, not for administering insulin.
C: Yes, an insulin pump can deliver insulin continuously and as needed, offering better control and greater freedom.
D: No, insulin must always be injected manually several times a day to be effective.

Question: HOW DO OTHER MEDICATIONS INTERACT WITH DIABETES?
A: Over-the-counter medications cannot interact with diabetes medications because they are less strong.
B: Some medications can affect your blood sugar by interacting with your diabetes treatments. Inform your doctor of all your medications.
C: Drug interactions for diabetes are only a problem if you are taking very strong medications like opioids.
D: Other medications can worsen diabetes, but only if you take them at the same time as your diabetes medication.

Question: How DO OTHER MEDICATIONS INTERACT With anti-DIABETES MEDICATIONS?
A: Antidiabetic medications always cancel out the effects of all other medications.
B: It is dangerous to take heart medication at the same time as antidiabetic medications.
C: Other medications can affect blood sugar levels when taken with diabetes drugs, potentially causing highs or lows. Always consult your doctor or pharmacist.
D: Antidiabetic medications have no interaction with other medications, so there is no need to worry.
